title: [API] Improve HeronSubmitter
body:
This PR aims the following changes:

- Current writing topology definition to `OutputStream` has been refactored with `try-with-resources` statement so explicit `flush` and `close` method calls have been removed.
- Redundant `directory check` has been removed.
- Added `UT` coverages for the following cases:
  - Success case (by submitting valid topology)
  - 4 negative cases 
    - If Tmp Directory is not set,
    - If Tmp Directory is set as empty path,
    - If Tmp Directory is set as invalid path,
    - `submitJar` is not supported yet
- `Javadocs` have been added.

Also: new added UT cases execution time is as follows:
//heron/api/tests/java:HeronSubmitterTest      PASSED in **3.8s**

title: add a switch for metricscache
body:
Added a switch to turn on/off metricscache. Config options:
```
heron.topology.metricscachemgr.mode: cluster
heron.topology.metricscachemgr.mode: disabled (default)
```

In some scenarios, the customers do not turn on healthmgr/dhalion, so the metricscache does not have consumer. This PR add a switch so that user can turn it off.

 - Scala `Function` to `SerializableFunction`
 - Scala `Sink` to Java `Sink`
Adding UT Coverages for both `Scala StreamletImpl` and `ScalaToJavaConverter`

title: add warning when `aurora job add` command fails during `heron update`
body:
replace #2733

After discussion with maosong and ning, we agree:
1 Warn users clearly before the actual update process. So they can know the risks. (done by prompt)
2 Warn users clearly after failure. And let users know the topology can enter a wired state, and a re-deployment is recommended. 

Since the warning tells the users to assure the topology's running state, heron does not try to activate it.

Example:
```
$ ~/bin/heron update --config-property heron.command.update.prompt=prompt \
--verbose local ExclamationTopology --component-parallelism word:4
```
Default config value `disabled`

title: Check that current process is not session master
body:
According to posix specification it is not permitted to change process group of session master. In this case setpgrp will fail with EPERM. Before calling setpgrp we should first check that current process is not a session master.

https://github.com/twitter/heron/issues/1177

title: Allow user to run kill command when some topology data is missing
body:
When kill or submit command is not fully successful, it is possible that there are some incomplete data for the topology. We need to allow users to run kill command in this case instead of rejecting it because of missing data.


Previous tries:
https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/2685
https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/2689

body: At the moment, there's a script that automatically performs a complete setup for people that want to build the site locally, including installing Node.js. The Node.js step, however, has proven to be quite error prone and a source of frustration for external contributors. I'd like to provide a better setup script down the road but for now, best to tell people to install these tools on their own.

title: mitigate prompt during installation
body:
The install.sh always prompts user to type `y` on my mac. See below
```
Uncompressing...done
tar xfz /Users/xxx/.heron/heron.tar.gz -C /Users/xxx/.heron
...Uncompressing.
tar xfz /Users/xxx/.heron/dist/heron-core.tar.gz -C /Users/xxx/.heron/dist
override r-xr-xr-x  xxx/yyy for /Users/xxx/.heron/dist/release.yaml? y

Heron is now installed!
```

This pr bypass user typing `y`
```
override r-xr-xr-x  xxx/yyy for /Users/xxx/.heron/dist/release.yaml? y
```

title: Move stmgr quitting logic from stmgr client to tmaster client
body:
We found out that when a bad stmgr is experiencing connection issue to
all other stmgrs, it takes the stmgr a lot longer to reach the per stmgr
client max attempt and quite becaus bad connections cause extra delays.
In our case, instead of quitting after 5 minutes (1s reconnect timeout,
300 max attempts), the bad stmgr quitted after more than 2 hours. At the
same time, all other good stmgrs were quitting every 5 minutes.

Here is a more detailed document about the issue:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1WHNc2NEp2gVL9ge2QVKp9t4Hpd4U9sAbzBqCu4-iDUM/edit#

body:
Our customers requires to reduce the exception stack trace size.
I found the spi comment (https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/heron/spi/src/java/com/twitter/heron/spi/metricsmgr/metrics/ExceptionInfo.java#L37) showing 'first 2 lines', but the present tmaster-metricscollector and metricscache, they include all lines. This PR reduces the metricscachesink to first 2 lines while keeping tmaster-metricscolletor untouched.

title: [Streamlet Scala API] Add Streamlet Trait Support
body:
This PR aims the following changes:

`Streamlet` Trait will be one of main container for Scala API so in the light of Scala User experiences, it needs to be pure Scala. In the light of this, please find the following changes:

- Accept pure Scala Function versions instead of the following Java `FunctionalInterfaces` in Streamlet Scala level.
       - `SerializableFunction`
       - `SerializablePredicate`
       - `SerializableBiFunction`
       - `SerializableBinaryOperator`
       - `SerializableConsumer`
- Use `scala.Iterable` instead of `java.lang.Iterable`
- Use `scala.Int` instead of `java.lang.Integer`
- Use `scala.collection.Seq` instead of `java.util.List`

**Note:** Streamlet UT coverages will be added against its **impl** level (`scala.StreamletImpl`) via next PRs.

title: Nwang/count stmgr connection failures in all clients
body:
We found out that when a bad stmgr is experiencing connection issue to
all other stmgrs, it takes the stmgr a lot longer to reach the per stmgr
client max attempt and quite becaus bad connections cause extra delays.
In our case, instead of quitting after 5 minutes (1s reconnect timeout,
300 max attempts), the bad stmgr quitted after more than 2 hours. At the
same time, all other good stmgrs were quitting every 5 minutes.

A total reconnection attempt checking is added in order to make the bad
stmgr quit sooner.

title: Call cleanState() before submitting topology in case previous kill co
body:
mmand wasn't fully successful and there is left-over data

Internal users reported an issue that a kill command is not fully successful. As the result there are some left over data in zk and users won't be able to submit the topology again. And because the key data has been deleted, "heron kill" command throws a "Topology 'test' does not exist" error when users tried to run it again.

It seems clearState() function deletes 8 nodes one by one and the delete calls don't guarantee to be successful. Now we call clearState() again in case there is any left over (unexpected) data. The validation code in submitMain is also updated to be consistent to the validation in RuntimeManager.

title: Add skip runtime validation option
body:
Internal users reported an issue that a kill command is not fully successful. As the result there are some left over data in zk. It seems clearState() function deletes 8 nodes one by one and the delete calls don't guarantee to be successful.

Because of these left over data, users can't deploy the topology.
And because some key data has been deleted, "heron kill" command throws a "Topology 'test' does not exist" error when users tried to run it again.

This new "skip-runtime-validation" option can be useful when a topolgoy is not "fully killed",
for example, topology is killed but data clean up is not successful,
to skip the runtime validation in order to run the kill command again

title: no need to check the existence of env_exec.sh in scripts/setup-intell
body:
This PR comes from #2681

After removing the heading`if` block, `./scripts/setup-intellij.sh` can run smoothly. I think for history reason, as was noted in PR #1429 , that heading`if` block was added to check the existence of `env_exec.sh`. But for now, the `env_exec.sh` file is not needed anymore.

title: Don't drop tuples during backpressure in DrainTupleStream
body:
It could be useful to not drop tuples in cross StMgr traffic:
1. we have visibility about the number of tuples dropped.
2. tuple dropping will be local (in one container/stmgr) instead in all containers. it could help investigation and maintenance.
3. some IO bandwidth will be wasted but the case should be rare (hopefully)

title: JSON output for heron-admin standalone cluster info command
body: At the moment, running `heron-admin standalone info` command outputs a formatted string. This PR changes the output to pretty-printed JSON so that the output can be easily stored in JSON files and used with tools like `jq`.

title: Clean up simulator/utils
body:
This is the first commit i'll be making to the simulator package, as I attempt to add stateful processing to the simulator pursuant to issue #2346.

This cleanup first removes a couple of unused classes from simulator/instance.

It also removes some odd programming paradigms which were used for the simulator utils, like a pseudo-static class that acts on an object and objects derived from it (PhysicalPlanUtil), a class that can only be instantiated by a static method which creates maps of itself (StreamConsumers), a class with an entirely unnecessary private constructor (XORManager) and general passing of directly derived objects instead of encapsulation. I've merged the PhysicalPlanUtil and StreamConsumers functionality into TopologyManager, a class which manages additional functionality for a single topology and its directly derived objects.

title: [hold][healthmgr] add backpressure-diagnoser
body:
1
The present `AutoRestartBackpressureContainerPolicy.java` actually means `slow instance`.
This PR renamed `AutoRestartBackpressureContainerPolicy.java` to `AutoRestartSlowContainerPolicy.java`.

2
Besides, this PR added `BackpressureInstanceDiagnoser.java` and true `AutoRestartBackpressureContainerPolicy.java`

The present issue is the 'slow instance' involves 3 detectors and it could be more flexible. Our users need better control.
The new `BackpressureInstanceDiagnoser` provides users flexibility in addition to `SlowInstanceDiagnoser`.

title: Fix for running topologies with DC/OS 1.10 or Marathon 1.5
body:
What?
- A bug fix for deploying topologies on DC/OS v1.10 and Marathon 1.5 where the Ids of the individual apps in the group didn't conform to the pattern needed
- An improvement to group all topologies within a `heron/topologies/` folder within marathon

Why?
- Could not previously deploy topologies on DC/OS v1.10 and Marathon 1.5

title: Use the minimal ram size for components instead of the last one
body:
Currently the component ram size calculation assumes all instances for a component use the same amount of memory, when generating component ram map. However this is not true for some packingplan algorithms, like RoundRobin. As the result, the bigger ram size can be used and the total memory used by instances in more crowded container can be more than the container ram size.

Example:
each container has 2G for instances.

container 1 has 1 "spout" and 1 "bolt", the ram size is 1G per instance
container 2 has 1 "bolt", the ram size is 2G per instance
The component ram map might be "spout:1g,bolt:1g" or "spout:1g,bolt:2g". In the second case, the instances in container 1 would use 3G memory, because the instances in the container would have the following jvm arguments:
spout 1: "-xmx 1g"
bolt 1: "-xmx 2g"

title: Joshfischer/eco config
body:
@kramasamy

This pull request contains the code to create Heron Topologies using ECO.  This would be considered a first pass to support defining topologies with Java based spouts and bolts.  The hope is that you can take any project that used Flux to create topologies and run them in Heron after following the steps here -> https://twitter.github.io/heron/docs/migrate-storm-to-heron/

An additional step is to include the eco-core in the Flux topology project as a dependency as well.  Imagine it would be something similar to the below in a Maven project:

```
<dependency>
        <groupId>com.twitter.heron</groupId>
        <artifactId>eco-core</artifactId>
        <version>0.0.97</version>
</dependency>

```
An example of how to submit an ECO topology would be as follows:
```
heron submit local ~/path/to/target/heron-example-jar-with-dependencies.jar \
 com.twitter.heron.eco.Eco \
  --eco-config-file /
~/path/to/yaml/simple_wordcount.yaml  
```

The "heron-example-jar-with-dependencies.jar" should contain all of the referenced spouts and bolts that are defined in the simple_wordcount.yaml file.

I will follow up with another pull request  soon to update the docs on the web on how to define ECO topology files, and what to expect with using ECO.

 Multi-lang functionality that Flux provided is still to be discussed. E.g., The flux shell wrappers 

```
<dependency>
        <groupId>org.apache.storm</groupId>
        <artifactId>flux-wrappers</artifactId>
        <version>${project.version}</version>
</dependency>
```

Do we want them pulled over to our project?  Would we like to rename them and so forth.

Also, since the verbose flag isn't considered an unknown argument it isn't passed on to the Eco.class to specify what level of logging to print.  As of now the only output from the ECO project should  be something similar to what Flux displayed while deploying the Storm topologies. Below is an example:

```
Jan 07, 2018 4:09:47 PM com.twitter.heron.eco.Eco printTopologyInfo
INFO: ---------- TOPOLOGY DETAILS ----------
Jan 07, 2018 4:09:47 PM com.twitter.heron.eco.Eco printTopologyInfo
INFO: Topology Name: sliding-window-topology
Jan 07, 2018 4:09:47 PM com.twitter.heron.eco.Eco printTopologyInfo
INFO: --------------- SPOUTS ---------------
Jan 07, 2018 4:09:47 PM com.twitter.heron.eco.Eco printTopologyInfo
INFO: spout-1 [1] (org.apache.storm.flux.examples.TestWordSpout)
Jan 07, 2018 4:09:47 PM com.twitter.heron.eco.Eco printTopologyInfo
INFO: ---------------- BOLTS ---------------
Jan 07, 2018 4:09:47 PM com.twitter.heron.eco.Eco printTopologyInfo
INFO: bolt-1 [1] (org.apache.storm.flux.examples.TestWindowBolt)
Jan 07, 2018 4:09:47 PM com.twitter.heron.eco.Eco printTopologyInfo
INFO: bolt-2 [1] (org.apache.storm.flux.examples.TestPrintBolt)
Jan 07, 2018 4:09:47 PM com.twitter.heron.eco.Eco printTopologyInfo
INFO: --------------- STREAMS ---------------
Jan 07, 2018 4:09:47 PM com.twitter.heron.eco.Eco printTopologyInfo
INFO: spout-1 --FIELDS--> bolt-1
Jan 07, 2018 4:09:47 PM com.twitter.heron.eco.Eco printTopologyInfo
INFO: bolt-1 --SHUFFLE--> bolt-2
Jan 07, 2018 4:09:47 PM com.twitter.heron.eco.Eco printTopologyInfo
INFO: -------------------------------------- 
```

It should also be noted that ECO topologies can only be assembled with spouts and bolts from Storm at this time.

I hope these details are sufficient enough.  Look forward to any thoughts or concerns.

title: Add support for custom evictor and trigger policies
body:
Hello,

Pursuant to my question in #2647 , I've added support for custom eviction and trigger policies.  The modifications that I have made is to:

-Add the ability to add a custom EvictionPolicy and TriggerPolicy to a WindowingConfigs
-Add an if statement to check for the existence of custom policies in the WindowingConfigs passed to a WindowedBoltExecutor
-Add the ability to add a custom trigger or evictor policy to a BaseWindowedBolt
-Add support for a custom trigger and evictor policy WindowConfig and WindowConfigImpl in the streamlet api

Thoughts? This is my first time interacting with the underlying api, but I tried to keep the methods/implementation as similar as possible to what already existed.

Daniel

-------------

Add support in both the streamlet and topology apis for the usage of custom eviction policies extending com.twitter.heron.api.windowing.EvictionPolicy and trigger policies extending com.twitter.heron.api.windowing.TriggerPolicy to enable user-defined windowing schemes.

title: Add a --heron-home option into heron-cli to specify lib/config directory
body:
Inside Twitter we need to support multi heron version and we need to be able to override paths to heron libs/configs in the internal tools.

This PR just refactor the two get_*_heron_dir() functions slightly so that the paths are available to be overridden beforehand if needed.
